It says a lot about me that the first Enrico the opera singer I thought of was... Enrico PALAZZO ü§£ https://youtu.be/6HA-lvIio78?si=rdJd6dZuUtVHaqO_ ≈öwiƒôty Miko≈Çaj, Saint Nicholas, is our most common term for Santa. We have no "for short" for him, so there is no Polish term akin to Santa as such. He has some regional names, too. For example, in Wielkopolska, the Western part of Poland, he's called Gwiazdor, litera≈Çy "the one with the star" - in this incarnation the character is a conflation of St. Nicholas and his traditional, folk counterpart of Wielkopolska lore, represented as a somewhat scary guy with a star over his head, and carrying a bag of presents but also a whip, to punish bad children. Folk stories, eh? When we were part of the Eastern Bloc, the Soviets tried to influence our culture by substituting their Russian Ded Moroz (Dziadek Mr√≥z, Father Frost) for ≈öwiƒôty Miko≈Çaj, but it never caught on. As for the puzzle, I think only Patti Varol ever stuffed her "Mondays" with more trivia than today's constructors did... I almost needed lookups üòê. So no, I didn't like it ü§∑üèΩ

For those in a bragging, competitive one-upmanship yay-me frame of mind, I tried (as usual) to complete the puzzle without using any of the down clues and I managed it in 14:08. Imagine my surprise when FLEEK, PIBB, TUBB, FALA, NTSB and TSE turned out to be correct! I‚Äôm quite relieved that I never looked at the downs!
did anyone else get stuck spelling ARTOO as ARTWO? oops!
Two Star Wars clues in a puzzle this small is a tad much imo (though two clues in any would be two too many for me personally I understand tastes differ)

To my surprise, even shock, I solved them all. It took me a while, I had to stop to remember eg Hoover's name and WALZ; I'd read an article about slang going out of date and it mentioned 'fleek'! 

US slang is usually my b√™te noir, unless from 1970's. When I visited California in 1975 'rad' was the very latest slang. 

I hardly ever get the theme, but here the 2nd BED really helped me solve a clue. I watch foreign language films so DUBBED was obvious, although I much prefer sub-titles. 

Excellent start to the week for me.

Back in the Mid 60‚Äôs as a teenaged (16) usher at a Walter Reade Theater I had to quell an eruption from a discontented audience at curtain time. This on account of the fact that the print of Bonnie and Clyde arrived from Hollyweird with the dialogue in Spanish; the 46a with English subtitles. There was as much popcorn airborne in the aisles as is in Blue Man Group shows.

Random thoughts:
‚Ä¢	Another graphic representation (in a crossword) of a type of bed could be a vertical BED abutting a vertical WALL, for a Murphy bed.
‚Ä¢	WOL (Words I Love): HOBNOBBED and BEDAZZLED.  
‚Ä¢	I also love ‚Äúbalderdash‚Äù, from a clue.  My TIL is its origin. Long ago, the word meant ‚Äúa jumbled mix of liquors‚Äù (such as milk and beer, or beer and wine), and moved from there to mean ‚Äúa senseless jumble of words‚Äù or ‚Äúutter nonsense‚Äù.
‚Ä¢	This is Tim WALZ‚Äôs first appearance in the Times puzzle, though he‚Äôs shown up a few times elsewhere.
‚Ä¢	Regarding KIDD on the eastern edge of the grid, the constructors took the phrase ‚Äúall kidding aside‚Äù quite seriously!
‚Ä¢	Lovely PuzzPair¬© of SOAK and TUBB.

Lovely side trips to enhance a fun solve ‚Äì thank you, Jeff and Acme.  And WTG, Jeff on you NYT debut!

Congrats on your debut Jeff! I thought this was a fine Monday puzzle.
Appropriate call out to Dick Van Dyke shortly after his birthday, 
Just awoke to the horrifying news of Rob Reiner‚Äôs passing. Unfortunately referenced in these pages most recently from Roger Ebert‚Äôs review of North.
But he has also consistently gotten love here for Princess Bride, This is Spinal Tap, Misery, A Few Good Men‚Ä¶the list goes on. For a last look, check out the Spjnal Tap sequel now streaming.

My last tribute will be a reference to my movie anagram puzzle a few years back:

M. Ryan‚Äîwhat‚Äôs her yell? (WHEN HARRY MET SALLY)

Thanks Rob for hours of entertainment, you will be missed.

And one more late puzzle find. In the vicinity of dad jokes, so definitely up my alley. Anyway - a Tuesday from December 10, 2019 by Eric Berlin. Three 15 letter grid-spanning theme answers. Here's those clues and answers: "At the big brawl, the jazz musician ..." CAMEOUTSWINGING "At the big brawl, the hairstylist ..." BOBBEDANDWEAVED "At the big brawl, the king and queen ..." PUTUPTHEIRDUKES Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/10/2019&g=36&d=A ....

Well, that was quite fun, especially for a Monday--the day when one is seldom slowed, stopped, stumped, or in suspense.
I waited for the DOUBLE BED joke to emerge, but instead... 
Then I waited to see what came after IT'S A B. S. --- (which didn't turn out as expected, either.)  

New--yucky icky--vocab:  On FLEEK.  The EEK part seems APT.
Where did this come from?-- (as in Under what rock was this discovered?)  It's even an ugly-LOOKing word.  Ugh ugh ugh.

I believe I'll ask DHubby to play some of our recordings (78 rpm) of Enrico CARUSO- Amelita Galli-Curci duets.... perhaps some with Tito Schipa as well.  Warm things up a bit; it was 18 degrees this morning.
Enjoyed the puzzle this frosty morning. Got out of BED to get coffee and returned to BED to complete it.  Or could that be just another BUNK BED story?

For a while, Mr. PIBB had been renamed "PIBB Xtra." It was a dark day for sugar-water connoisseurs. I refused to call it that; it sounded undignified.

Thankfully, it's been re-rebranded as Mr. PIBB, and sanity has been restored to the world.

So here's an important tip: when you're in an interrogation room and the detectives ask if you take credit cards, they're not just making conversation.

Do not say "Yes, we do."

Unless you really like bunk beds.
Three people in 2014 used the work FLEEK and somehow, that became a NYT crossword answer?  Crosses were easy but really?  Yuk.
Happy 100th Birthday, Dick van Dyke.

Sam, my most memorable experience calling dibs was, ironically, in my college dorm room when I pulled what ended up being the short straw to sleep on the top bunk. The problem was that my roommate (on the cozy bottom bunk) liked to crank up the heat which made sleeping on the top feel like I was in the rainforest. In the middle of each night I would jump off my bunk and turn down (or turn off) the heat. Of course, this was just one of many roommate tales... The following semester I called dibs on the bottom bunk.
Lots of fun. Really enjoyed it.

@Steve L -- I got emu-ed, I'm guessing for the word BUTT, which I spelled out.  So I did it again as you can see above, and it came right up!

@Steve L - I see dubbed films every week on Telemundo, when they dub Turkish serial dizis into Spanish telenovelas.

@jennie

That doesn't save them from being "green paint."  

Green paint is when the two word--usually adjective + noun--have no unique meaning other than the meanings of the individual words (or aren't common phrases in their literal sense, like Sunday's "altered states").

In other words, a dubbed film is nothing more than a film that is dubbed.  Just like green paint is just paint that is paint that is green.

Here are some examples of non-green paint:

Green design.  Not a design colored green, but eco-friendly design.

From the puzzle:  Bad seed.  Not a seed unable to produce a plant, but a rotten person.

From Saturday:  Red ape. Because it's the name of a specific primate, it's not "green paint." (Similarly from Saturday, "hot pink," a specific shade of pink.  Actual green paint is not a specific category of paint.  (But latex paint is a specific category of paint, so it isn't "green paint," regardless of what color it is.)

However, add a T to "red ape," and you have "red tape," which isn't green paint.  "Red tape" normally refers to bureaucracy, not tape that is red.  On the other hand, pink, brown or purple tape would be green paint.

I know it's confusing, but I hope this helps!

@Steve L
Can DUBBED FILM for [Foreign-language movie that you don‚Äôt have to read subtitles for] really count as a good example of green paint when the answer is immediately gettable from the clue? You know it‚Äôs going to be DUBBED something, and ‚Äúmovie‚Äù was already used in the clue, so DUBBED FILM is the only plausible answer.

That seems rather distinct from Rex Parker‚Äôs criticisms of SAUT√â PAN for [Vessel for frying food] from 12/13/2018 and actual BEIGE PAINT for [Unflashy coat] from 12/5/2012.

Surely, the crossword term of art is meant to criticize the effect that one‚Äôs use in a grid has on the solve, and doesn‚Äôt simply mean literally any pairing of words that aren‚Äôt a set phrase.

@Nick
Interesting examples from Rex Parker. I'd say SAUT√â PAN is not 'green paint' but that BEIGE PAINT obviously is. A saut√© pan has unique characteristics beyond its mere pan-ness and the apposite noun is distinctive. Ditto for cr√™pe pan, omelette pan,  but maybe not for frying pan, and certainly not for brown pan. It is a tricky line to draw.

@SBK

Frying pan - not green paint
Brown pan - green paint
Cast Iron Pan - not green paint
Metal pan - green paint.

Steve,
But a DUBBED FILM and a subtitled film 
are very real and very distinct things, 
like a crepe pan and a cast iron pan.

@Barry Ancona I suppose it's a subjective matter, but I don't think "dubbed film" and "subtitled film" are "in the language" the way "action film" is, for example. And I have statistics: https://tinyurl.com/3fk547km The phrase that seems "in the language" to me is "dubbed version," and I have statistics here, too: https://tinyurl.com/mrbddmmh Because the film itself is not intrinsically dubbed; if it is shown in the countries where its original language is spoken, it's not a dubbed film. Feel free not to be convinced; as I said, it just feels that way to me.

Far more common clues, numbered in the dozens, are for [Mao ___-tung] (outdated now), [Lao-___]. Also, you'll find the monogram of T. S. Eliot, the initials for the Japanese stock market as well as the Toronto one, another Chinese guy K'ug Fu-___ (Confucius), and a Cyrillic alphabet letter. That's out of 421 appearances. Also, most Poles live in condos, not detached houses, and they tend to be small, especially by American standards. I had my own room in the 1980s, but it was tiny, some 5 square meters. To give me more space, my parents had a bunk bed made, but one with only the upper bunk - the space below thus could be used as part of my living space.

The living area of the condo my wife and I live in now is the size of the whole place my family owned in the 80s and 90s.

@ad absurdum
I will always watch "The American President", no matter how often or how recently I've seen it. It's beautifully constructed and has one of my favourite never-seen characters, the father of the reporter played by Annette Bening. He exists in a few lines of dialogue by her,  describing his probable reaction to a vicious slander against his daughter.  It's a staccato painting in words.

@Kelly H. I had crazy roommate bunkbed story too!  There was overcrowding in my freshman dorm so they put in a bunk bed even tho only one desk, one lamp, one chair, etc.

My roommate never used to even pause for a breath when talking, like she had been told to shut up her whole life.  She was exceedingly bright and actually quite nice, but if I would get up in the middle of the night to use the bathroom, I'd come back and she'd have compulsively made my bed!!!

Freaked me out and I requested (and received) a transfer after less than a week.

Wow, I hadn't really thought about this in almost 50 years!

@Andrea Carla Michaels

Thanks for sharing, Andrea -- I, too, had almost forgotten about my roommate trials and tribulations after so many years. Your compulsive roommate sounds nice, but exhausting! None of my roommates ever did make my bed, however -- day OR night!üòÇ
